headline: States to Move Forward With Antitrust Probe of Big Tech Firms
summary: A group of state attorneys general is preparing to move forward with a joint antitrust investigation of big technology companies, according to people familiar with the situation, adding another layer of scrutiny to an industry already under a federal spotlight.

headline: Twitter, Facebook Act Against Disinformation on Hong Kong Protests
summary: Twitter took down more than 900 accounts that it said were part of a Chinese government campaign to discredit protesters in Hong Kong by spreading misinformation.

headline: Trump Urges Restraint by India and Pakistan in Kashmir Conflict
summary: President Trump urged restraint on both sides of the Kashmir conflict in calls with the leaders of India and Pakistan, as tensions over the disputed region have escalated between the two nations this month.

headline: HUD Proposal Raises Bar on Housing Discrimination Complaints
summary: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is moving to roll back an Obama-era policy aimed at rooting out racial bias in housing, the latest move by the Trump administration to weaken a legal tool combating unintentional discrimination.

headline: For Eric Garner’s Family, NYPD Officer’s Firing Was Long Overdue
summary: The firing of the New York Police Department Officer Daniel Pantaleo, who was involved in the 2014 death of Eric Garner, drew strong reactions, but Mr. Garner’s family said it brought little comfort after years of waiting.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Aug. 20, 2019

headline: Tesla to Rent Solar Panels to Homeowners
summary: Tesla is trying to inject new energy into its solar business by offering to rent panels in six states. Customers can cancel at anytime.

headline: Trump Calls for a Big Fed Rate Cut, Again Criticizes Powell
summary: President Trump called for the Fed to sharply cut interest rates and again criticized the central bank’s chairman for a “horrendous lack of vision,” while reiterating his belief that the U.S. economy is strong.

headline: Pakistan Extends Powerful Army Chief’s Term
summary: Pakistan’s army chief will serve another three years as the country deals with the Afghanistan peace process and tension with India.

headline: New York City Union Uses Its Size to Leverage Improved Maternity Care
summary: In a bid to provide better health outcomes for pregnant women and reduce health care costs, one of New York City’s largest unions is pushing local hospital systems to create specialty maternity-care networks.

headline: Final Bows Boost Broadway Ticket Sales
summary: A number of shows have closed on Broadway this month. But they are not ending their runs without a burst of box-office glory.

headline: McKinsey Dodges Lawsuit Targeting Its Bankruptcy Disclosures
summary: A federal judge dismissed a racketeering lawsuit brought against McKinsey & Co. by turnaround industry veteran Jay Alix, who claimed the consulting firm profited by failing to disclose conflicts of interest in bankruptcy cases.

headline: Trump Is Losing the Trade War With China
summary: The markets doubt tariffs will bring about any major concessions. The U.S. needs a multilateral approach.

headline: The Fed Has Too Much to Do
summary: Let private companies run the payments system. The central bank is already overextended.

headline: Free-Marketeers Have Taken Social Conservatives for Granted
summary: Capitalists need to make the case that prosperity is crucial for protecting tradition and security.

headline: ‘The Twenty-Six Words That Created the Internet’ Review: Protecting the Providers
summary: Section 230 protects websites and online service providers from liability for what their users post. Has the time come to rethink it?

headline: A Forbidden Word’s Lost Lessons
summary: A professor is under investigation for accurately quoting James Baldwin.

headline: Apologize, Carrie Lam

summary: New Delhi is a major trading partner and powerful friend in a dangerous region.

headline: Top CEOs Say Firms Have Duties Beyond Shareholder Value

headline: Beauty Stocks Look Pretty After Upbeat Estée Lauder Earnings
summary: Investors are still betting on cosmetic companies despite the retail sector’s tariff woes.

headline: More Russian Nuclear Monitoring Stations Go Silent Days After Blast, Official Says
summary: The number of Russian nuclear monitoring stations that have gone silent has doubled to four, an international arms-control official said Monday, heightening concerns among observers that Russia is trying to hide evidence from an explosion at a missile-test site earlier this month.

headline: Lumber Liquidators Names New Chief Financial Officer
summary: Lumber Liquidators Holdings named former Pier 1 Imports Inc. finance chief Nancy Walsh as its new chief financial officer.

headline: Two Drugmakers Closing In on Opioid Settlements
summary: Drugmakers Endo International and Allergan are in talks to avoid going to a landmark trial set to begin in October over the opioid crisis, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Visium Sues Widow of Portfolio Manager Who Died by Suicide
summary: A hedge fund that closed after securities regulators accused the firm of insider trading is seeking more than $100 million from the estate of one of its former portfolio managers.

headline: An Economic Warning Sign: RV Shipments Are Slipping
summary: Multiyear drops in recreational-vehicle shipments to dealers—many from the Elkhart, Ind., region—have preceded the last three downturns. Shipments have fallen about 20% so far this year, after a 4.1% drop last year.

headline: Data-Center Market Is Booming Amid Shift to Cloud
summary: Data centers are hot properties, even as many businesses are shedding them to shift their information-technology operations online.

headline: Oil Rises on Trade Hopes
summary: Oil prices rose, fueled by hopes of progress in trade relations between China and the U.S.

headline: Big Business and its ‘Stakeholders’

headline: U.S. Prisons Chief Removed in Wake of Epstein Suicide
summary: The acting chief of the federal Bureau of Prisons has been ousted from his post following the suicide of disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein in a New York detention facility as he faced sex trafficking charges.

headline: GE Issues New Rebuttal to Whistleblower’s Claims on Finances

headline: Justice Department Drops Foreign Bribery Probe Into Medical Device Maker

headline: PG&E Plunges After Judge Allows Trial

headline: Warren Apologizes at Native American Forum
summary: Sen. Elizabeth Warren apologized to a largely Native American audience for “harm I have caused” after years of occasionally identifying herself as Native American, as well as for releasing a DNA test last year that she said supported her ancestry claims.

headline: The ‘Stakeholder’ CEOs
summary: Executives who abandon shareholders won’t appease the socialists.

headline: Investors Start to Cool on Utilities
summary: Utility stocks haven’t been climbing in August as much as some analysts and investors might expect given the sharp drop in bond yields recently.

headline: Citrix Names New CFO as It Steers Toward Cloud-Based Business Model
summary: Citrix Systems Inc. hired a new finance chief as the software maker transitions toward a more cloud- and subscription-based business model.

headline: Accountability for Epstein’s Death
summary: Bill Barr deserves credit for cleaning house at the Bureau of Prisons.

headline: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Germany?
summary: Berlin prepares to cave to the Keynesians but could do so much better.

summary: U.S. stocks kicked off the week with gains, buoyed by a rally among shares of banks and technology companies.

summary: New York Police Department Officer Daniel Pantaleo, who faced disciplinary charges over the 2014 death of Eric Garner, has been terminated from his job.

summary: The claim that an independent Western Sahara would likely be unstable and offer a foothold to Islamic State is misguided conjecture.

headline: Congress Must Resolve the Internet Sales-Tax Fiasco
summary: I can only wish that those on the Supreme Court who voted for Wayfair could come into my small business of six employees to see what it’s like to deal with this unmitigated disaster on daily basis.

headline: States Wanting Investment Must Be Fair to Business
summary: Kansas and Missouri can do even more to attract business by enacting civil justice reforms that improve their legal climates.

headline: Fed’s Rosengren Still Doesn’t See Need to Lower Rates
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren remains worried that central bank interest-rate cuts are unwarranted and could destabilize the financial sector—but signaled he’s open to action if convinced the economy was taking a turn for the worse.

headline: U.S. Government Bond Yields Rise as Treasury Again Explores Ultralong Bonds
summary: The Treasury Department’s latest expression of interest in issuing bonds with 50-year and 100-year maturities weighed on demand for existing Treasurys on Monday.

summary: Clarinetist and composer Ben Goldberg created recordings inspired by the poetry of Dean Young, who then wrote more poems in response to the music.

headline: Norsk Hydro Tests AI in Cyber Defenses After Attack
summary: The Norwegian aluminum company’s investigation of a ransomware attack it suffered in March has revealed new vulnerabilities, leading it to test using artificial intelligence to secure its industrial equipment.

headline: Trial Date Set in Women’s Suit Against U.S. Soccer
summary: A trial date has been set in the U.S. women’s soccer team’s pay-discrimination suit against the U.S. Soccer Federation: May 5, 2020.

headline: Two Members of Far-Right Group Proud Boys Found Guilty for Role in Manhattan Brawl
summary: Two members of the far-right group Proud Boys were found guilty of multiple charges, including attempted gang assault and attempted assault, for their role in a 2018 brawl in New York.

headline: Estée Lauder Reports Strong Sales Fueled by Asian Shoppers
summary: Estée Lauder projected strong growth in 2020 after the company reported sales increases in Asia and higher demand for its premium skincare brands, sending shares of the company to an all-time high

headline: Next Door to Hong Kong, Little Sympathy for the Protesters
summary: Shenzhen residents are more culturally linked to Hong Kong than many in China, but conversations with citizens revealed no taste for the kind of anti-government rebellion that has gripped their neighbors since June.

headline: U.S. Bank Regulator Pitches Low-Income Lending Rule Changes
summary: A Trump-appointed bank regulator is touring the country trying to sell his plans to modify lower-income lending requirements and overcome resistance from other regulators, banks and community advocates.

headline: Pirates Kidnap Crew Members From Two Ships Off Cameroon
summary: Armed attackers kidnapped 17 crew members from German and Greek vessels in piracy-troubled waters off the coast of Cameroon in two incidents last week and are seeking “huge sums” for their release, people involved in the matter said.

headline: Auto-Insurance Startup Root Insurance Rides Growth to $3.65 Billion Valuation
summary: New investors DST Global and Coatue Management are leading a proposed investment of $350 million in Root Insurance Co., according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: The Multiple Problems, and Potential Fixes, With the Boeing 737 MAX
summary: Two fatal crashes of Boeing’s 737 MAX have shown the vulnerabilities of the aircraft’s flight-control system. Here’s a look at the problems and how the company plans to fix them.

headline: Can Dancing Prevent Dementia?
summary: A new study is looking at the cognitive benefits of group dance classes, in hopes of discovering new tools to prevent dementia.

headline: Things Can Get Worse for Japan’s Struggling Regional Banks
summary: Ultralow interest rates are making it a miserable year for Japanese banks, with many stocks hitting historic lows. The bad news is that things can still get worse.

headline: Airbnb’s First-Quarter Financials Show Strong Growth Rate, Cash Reserves
summary: The San Francisco-based travel company had about $3.5 billion in cash on its balance sheet as of March 31, according to multiple people familiar with Airbnb’s finances. Technology businesses often drown in marketing costs, but Airbnb has been able to grow while keeping these expenditures in line.

summary: Last week’s yield-curve inversion might have been a good sign for the stock market’s biggest laggard this year: energy stocks.

summary: Nordstrom and DXC Technology are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Monday’s session.

headline: If Economy Sours, Democrats Will Face a Tough Choice
summary: Which Democratic candidate would benefit more from a recession: a moderate such as Joe Biden, or a candidate offering sharp changes like Sen. Elizabeth Warren? Primary and general-election voters may disagree, Gerald F. Seib writes.

headline: Domino’s Goes It Alone on Delivery
summary: The pizza chain that helped popularize delivery is keeping its pies off other services that allow diners to order all manner of cuisines to their doors.

summary: With locations in London and Lisbon, coworking space Second Home arrives in East Hollywood with its anti-clubby policies that aim to cultivate an eclectic mix of tenants

summary: The discreet charm of the ’70s makes an appearance in this season’s tailored skirts, tweeds, trench coats and reimagined suits—inside your fall wardrobe

headline: 2020 Democrats See Favorability Ratings Slide
summary: Three leading Democratic presidential candidates are viewed more negatively by Americans than they are positively, a new WSJ/NBC News poll finds.

headline: Pot Industry Underestimates Old-School Dealers
summary: Traditional drug dealers are still formidable competitors in states where cannabis is legal. Governments planning for huge tax windfalls and investors expecting rapid market-share gains have to adjust to a slower burn.

headline: Deadline Looms for U.S. Employers to Report Pay for Women, Minorities
summary: U.S. companies are preparing to give federal regulators the most detailed information ever collected about how they compensate workers of all genders, races and ethnicities.

headline: New York Gov. Cuomo Names New State Economic Czar
summary: Eric Gertler, a lawyer and publishing executive, will be nominated as the next leader of New York state’s economic development agency, a state official said.

headline: Iranian Tanker Heads to Greece After Leaving Gibraltar
summary: The Iranian tanker released by Gibraltar was sailing to Greece, according to ship-tracking data, as Tehran warned the U.S. against targeting the vessel after a last-minute attempt to seize it in the British overseas territory.

headline: Japan’s Wartime Emperor Showed Remorse Over Nanjing Massacre
summary: The late Emperor Hirohito privately expressed regret about atrocities committed by Japanese troops in the Chinese city of Nanjing in 1937, saying he hadn’t fully known what the army was doing but wished he could have stopped it, according to newly released records.

headline: A Private Word With Hirtle Callaghan’s Stephen Vaccaro
summary: Stephen Vaccaro, the new head of private equity at Hirtle Callaghan, shares his thoughts on the challenges facing today’s limited partners, lessons learned from prior downturns and advice for managers on the fundraising trail.

headline: Airbus Harnessing AI in Bid to Save Millions on Finance Tasks
summary: Airbus is using artificial intelligence to squeeze cost out of its finance function, an experiment launched in the aircraft maker’s Americas division that could save the corporation millions of dollars annually if rolled out in other regions.

headline: Hong Kong Leader Faces Pressure to Start Talks After Peaceful March
summary: By holding a massive peaceful march after two months of tear-gas-soaked demonstrations, Hong Kong’s pro-democracy movement has stepped up pressure on the city’s Beijing-backed leader Carrie Lam to enter into dialogue to resolve the crisis.

headline: Investors Seek Havens as Growth Fears Persist
summary: Investors are snapping up safer assets including gold, dividend-paying stocks and the Japanese yen, underlining anxiety over trade tensions and slowing global growth.

headline: Viacom, CBS Executives to Earn Big From Merger
summary: Bob Bakish, who will become president and CEO of ViacomCBS, has signed a contract worth about $31 million a year. Joe Ianniello, who will be chairman and CEO of CBS at the combined company, will get earn about $70 million when the deal closes.

headline: Planned Parenthood to Leave Title X Program Over Abortion Rule
summary: Planned Parenthood will withdraw from the federal Title X family-planning program rather than comply with a new Trump administration rule preventing clinics from referring patients for abortions.

headline: Argentina’s Fernández Moves From Little-Known Politician to Next Likely President
summary: The surprisingly strong candidacy of Alberto Fernández is roiling markets amid investor concern about a return to power of the populist Peronist movement in Argentina.

headline: Legal Tussle Prevents $2.5 Billion Gas Pipeline to Mexico From Opening
summary: Mexico’s state-owned power utility is seeking nearly $900 million from delays in construction of a $2.5 billion natural-gas pipeline from Texas, preventing the finished project from opening despite energy shortages in some parts of the country.

headline: ‘Adult Recess’ Is Booming, Because Being a Grown-Up Is Hard
summary: Decades from elementary school, people are reliving schoolyard memories with tetherball, hopscotch and Lincoln Logs at “adult recess” events, despite sore muscles and tweaked knees; “I thought back to the last time when I really had fun.”

headline: The 2019 Oakland Raiders: Just Laugh, Baby
summary: The Oakland Raiders try to relocate their fearsome image—and find a new helmet for their star wide receiver.

headline: Jennifer Lopez, Alex Rodriguez Are Investing in Fintech Firm Acorns
summary: Acorns Grow wants to go viral–and it has enlisted A-Rod and J.Lo to help. The influencer strategy is the brainchild of Acorns CEO Noah Kerner, who is trying to transform the company from a niche savings app into a bank alternative.

headline: The ‘Overqualified’ Trap Can Hit You at Any Time
summary: You don’t have to be near retirement to battle a perception that you’ve accomplished too much. Here’s what to do about it.
